title: Call back number not verified
vulnerability_information:
The issue is with the "Confirm via call functionality" 

While adding mobile number,the application does not verify the number that is being called back. A malicious user can change the number to any premium rate numbers which charge particular amount from the caller.

It was further noticed that there was not limit to number of tries that can be made from the application. Even if the call is answered, same request can be used multiple times and the application still calls back.

The attached screenshot shows that the phone number value can be changed and premium rate numbers can be used. The number used while testing is a test call number for Eurocall24 (premium number provider).

An attacker can thereby steal money by manipulating the request to make call to premium numbers.

Affected functionality:  /phone_numbers/create
vulnerability_information_html:
The issue is with the "Confirm via call functionality"

While adding mobile number,the application does not verify the number that is being called back. A malicious user can change the number to any premium rate numbers which charge particular amount from the caller.

It was further noticed that there was not limit to number of tries that can be made from the application. Even if the call is answered, same request can be used multiple times and the application still calls back.

The attached screenshot shows that the phone number value can be changed and premium rate numbers can be used. The number used while testing is a test call number for Eurocall24 (premium number provider).

An attacker can thereby steal money by manipulating the request to make call to premium numbers.

Affected functionality: /phone_numbers/create

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

I believe that this endpoint should be rate limited to prevent repeated calls as you are describing.  Are you saying that you are not encountering rate limiting of any kind?  If so, can you provide more information about the tests you performed?  Can you please confirm which specific endpoint you were sending these requests to?  How many requests were you ultimately able to send?  How fast were you able to send these requests?  Additionally, are you actually altering the phone number via an intercepting proxy or through the normal interface?

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

I believe that this endpoint should be rate limited to prevent repeated calls as you are describing. Are you saying that you are not encountering rate limiting of any kind? How many requests were you ultimately able to send? How fast were you able to send these requests? Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Hello Josh,

I have attached a word document for your reference, please have a look.

Below are the response for your query:

1) I believe that this endpoint should be rate limited to prevent repeated calls as you are describing - Yes, rate limit should be maximum 3-5, moreover it's not just about rate limit. The numbers should be verified. There is difference between a normal mobile number and a premium number, application should check that. Because even if you rate the limit to 3-5, an attacker can just create more accounts.

2) Are you saying that you are not encountering rate limiting of any kind? - I tried more than 5 times. I think that should be enough to steal considerable amount of money.

3) If so, can you provide more information about the tests you performed? - I have attached a word document for your reference.

4) Can you please confirm which specific endpoint you were sending these requests to - POST /phone_numbers/create

5)  How many requests were you ultimately able to send? - 8 requests

6) How fast were you able to send these requests? - without any throttle, continuously

7) are you actually altering the phone number via an intercepting proxy or through the normal interface? - I used burp suite proxy.

Let me know if you need any more information.

activities.message:
Apologies for the delayed response, @al7311 This ticket seems to have fallen through the cracks.

We appreciate your time and effort but we're going to close this issue as informative. We do not consider this a technical vulnerability.
activities.markdown_message:
Apologies for the delayed response, @al7311 This ticket seems to have fallen through the cracks.

We appreciate your time and effort but we're going to close this issue as informative. We do not consider this a technical vulnerability.

activities.message:
I respect your decision of closing this issue as informative, But I don't agree with your statement of it not being a technical vulnerability. If the team had took it seriously to look into it. You would have come across information, where same issue was found (https://www.onthewire.io/making-money-by-abusing-phone-based-two-step-verification/)
and looked into in a serious manner. Well any ways thank you.

activities.message:
@al7311 Thank you for following up. The article you sent is very informative.

We were able to locate your request using the phone number you provided and we have confirmed no call was placed to the number. We have mitigations in place to protect against placing calls to premium numbers.
activities.markdown_message:
@al7311 Thank you for following up. The article you sent is very informative.

We were able to locate your request using the phone number you provided and we have confirmed no call was placed to the number. We have mitigations in place to protect against placing calls to premium numbers.

activities.message: @tyler_nichols. The application gave me positive response when I used premium number same response that I got when I called my own number. The document that I had attached shows the same.
activities.markdown_message: @tyler_nichols. The application gave me positive response when I used premium number same response that I got when I called my own number. The document that I had attached shows the same.

activities.message: @al7311 I noticed that in the screenshot you sent. The server logs indicate the phone number was identified as a premium number and that the call was not placed because it is considered invalid. At this point we are looking into the positive response as a UI bug rather than an exploitable vulnerability.
activities.markdown_message: @al7311 I noticed that in the screenshot you sent. The server logs indicate the phone number was identified as a premium number and that the call was not placed because it is considered invalid. At this point we are looking into the positive response as a UI bug rather than an exploitable vulnerability.

activities.message:
We were able to verify that the call was not sent.

We have mechanisms in place for determining the validity of user-provided phone numbers based on several metrics, one of which is whether the provided number is a premium number. This mechanism acted appropriately in this case, regardless of the success message that was returned to the client.
